original_data.question: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. Six months ago, she was vaccinated against influenza. Her last mammography 1 year ago showed no abnormalities. Two years ago, a pap smear and colonoscopy were normal. She has a history of hypertension. Her father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 50 years. She emigrated from Japan 30 years ago. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the last 18 years. She drinks 4â€“5 glasses of wine per day. She goes ballroom dancing twice each week. Her medications include enalapril and low-dose aspirin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a soft S4 gallop. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

model_response:
The patient's age and history of smoking place her at risk for coronary artery disease (CAD). The absence of abnormalities on cardiopulmonary examination and resting ECG does not exclude CAD. Exercise ECG (stress test) is less sensitive than exercise echocardiography or exercise radionuclide imaging for detecting CAD. Exercise echocardiography is generally more sensitive than exercise radionuclide imaging for detecting CAD. However, in this case, exercise echocardiography is not an option. Dual-energy x-ray bone absorptiometry is used to estimate bone mineral density and is not relevant here. Abdominal ultrasonography is not indicated in the absence of abdominal complaints. Pap smear is important for this sexually active woman, but it is not as important as screening for CAD. Transesophageal echocardiography is not indicated in the absence of symptoms such as dysphagia or unexplained weight loss. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is stress testing.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
An unvarying or habitual method or procedure.
The state of the organism when it functions optimally without evidence of disease.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Emotional sensations.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Radiographic examination of the breast.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the luminal surface of the colon.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

Persistently high systemic arterial BLOOD PRESSURE. Based on multiple readings (BLOOD PRESSURE DETERMINATION), hypertension is currently defined as when SYSTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently greater than 140 mm Hg or when DIASTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently 90 mm Hg or more.
Male parents, human or animal.
Irreversible cessation of all bodily functions, manifested by absence of spontaneous breathing and total loss of cardiovascular and cerebral functions.
NECROSIS of the MYOCARDIUM caused by an obstruction of the blood supply to the heart (CORONARY CIRCULATION).
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
A country in eastern Asia, island chain between the North Pacific Ocean and the Sea of Japan, east of the Korean Peninsula. The capital is Tokyo.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Roll of dried and finely cut TOBACCO leaves wrapped in a cylinder of thin paper used for SMOKING.
Occurring or done each day.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
A single serving of a beverage; any liquid suitable for drinking.

A pair of ophthalmic lenses in a frame or mounting which is supported by the nose and ears. The purpose is to aid or improve vision. It does not include goggles or nonprescription sun glasses for which EYE PROTECTIVE DEVICES is available.
Fermented juice of fresh grapes or of other fruit or plant products used as a beverage.
Occurring or done each day.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
An angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor that is used to treat HYPERTENSION and HEART FAILURE.
A reduced quantity of a therapeutic agent prescribed to be taken at one time or at stated intervals.

The prototypical analgesic used in the treatment of mild to moderate pain. It has anti-inflammatory and antipyretic properties and acts as an inhibitor of cyclooxygenase which results in the inhibition of the biosynthesis of prostaglandins. Aspirin also inhibits platelet aggregation and is used in the prevention of arterial and venous thrombosis. (From Martindale, The Extra Pharmacopoeia, 30th ed, p5)
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
Pertaining to both the heart and the lungs.

The fourth heart sound (S4) is a low-pitched sound that occurs just before the first heart sound (S1) when the atria contract to force blood into the left ventricle, that is, coincident with late diastolic filling of the ventricle due to atrial contraction. []
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
